Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Timely Power-Aware Data Management in Embedded Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
In emerging embedded and cyber physical applications like smart cars, micro grids, and homeland security, data amounts are increasing fast. Database support is essential in data-intensive embedded applications, because developing them without database support is hard and error-prone. Ideally, a database system needs to process real-time data service requests, such as driving route recommendations and electricity demand/supply analysis, in a timely manner using fresh data representing the current real-world status, e.g., the present traffic or electric grid status. It is also important the database should consume minimal power considering stringent power constraints in embedded systems. Achieving this vision is challenging for several reasons, including dynamic workloads varying in time depending on the current real world status, severe data/resource contention, and computational costs for updating temporal data. Moreover, the timeliness, data freshness, and power efficiency may compete with each other. If higher priority is given to user queries, their timeliness can be improved at the cost of the decreased data freshness or vice-versa. Simply consuming more power to support the desired timeliness and data freshness is not desirable. Unfortunately, state-of-the-art database systems may fall short of power-aware real-time data services. Non-real-time databases unaware of timing and data freshness requirements may perform poorly in these applications. Most existing real-time and embedded databases can provide no guarantee on the desired timeliness and data freshness. Neither are they power-aware. This can be a serious problem, since the unbounded tardiness or data staleness may result in a traffic jam, power outage, or homeland security problem. Although research on energy-efficient databases mainly in data center contexts has recently begun, real-time deadlines and data freshness requirements are not considered. Despite the importance, related work on power management in real-time databases, chiefly targeting embedded applications, is surprisingly scarce. Due to the power ignorance, deploying real-time databases may become increasingly difficult and costly. To bridge the gap, in-depth research will be performed in this work to investigate effective fundamental approaches for power-aware real-time data services in emerging embedded and cyber physical systems with significant broader impacts.

This project will investigate novel methods to support the desired timeliness and data freshness even in the presence of dynamic workloads, while substantially decreasing the power consumption in real-time embedded databases (RTEDBs). This will involve exploring 1) application of adaptive control theoretic techniques to gracefully adapt the RTEDB system behavior, if necessary, to support the desired timeliness and data freshness for less power in the closed-loop system; 2) feedforward methods to avoid data/resource contention incurring performance and power penalties by considering RTEDB semantics; 3) a multicore RTEDB system architecture, in which the cores support the desired timeliness and data freshness, decreasing the power usage both autonomously and collaboratively; and 4) extensive simulations and experiments in a testbed will be performed using real-world data traces to measure the timeliness, data freshness, and power and energy consumption.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In emerging embedded and cyber-physical applications, such as smart cars, microgrids, medical devices, and homeland security, it is desirable to process real-time data service requests in a timely manner using fresh data representing the current real-world status, while consuming less power precious in embedded systems. Achieving this objective is challenging due to time-varying workloads depending on the current real-world status, severe data/resource contention, and computational costs for updating temporal data. Moreover, the timeliness, data freshness, and power efficiency may compete with each other. Unbounded tardiness or data staleness may result in a traffic jam, power outage, or homeland security problem. Due to the power ignorance, deploying real-time data engines may become increasingly difficult and costly. To tackle the challenges, this project has investigated several effective approaches for power-aware real-time data services in emerging embedded/cyber-physical systems (CPS) and the Internet of Things (IoT) with significant broader impacts. Especially, the project has focused on improving the timeliness and power/energy efficiency for real-time sensor data processing and transfer. Key outcomes of this work include the following:

a)     New approaches for real-time query aggregation and data freshness adaptation in uniprocessor and multiprocessor real-time embedded databases to reduce both the deadline miss ratio and power consumption, unlike most existing approaches that perform trade-offs between the timeliness and power efficiency, by merging similar queries together and adapting the freshness of less popular data in a controlled manner

b)    A link-correlation-aware cross-layer protocol for IoT devices to enhance the packet transmission rate via link-correlation-aware forwarding and receiver-initiated acknowledgement

c)     A new approach for traffic intersection management that reduces the latency for vehicles to cross an intersection via efficient vehicle batching and scheduling

d)    An adaptive closed-loop approach for timely data services that applies adaptive control theoretic techniques to support the desired timeliness of real-time user transactions/queries even in the presence of dynamic workloads

e)    An effective approach to detect spoofing attack on automotive radars by applying real-time data analysis techniques, leveraging spatiotemporal semantics of sensor data and fundamental physics of automotive radars

f)      An in-memory real-time MapReduce framework that analyzes big sensor data in a timely manner, while minimizing I/O overhead via in-memory real-time data analysis

g)    A suite of 5G real-time communication techniques to reduce latency and enhance throughput:

  • Throughput enhancement via multi-armed bandit in heterogeneous networks
  • Index modulation for 5G MIMO-OFDM
  • Downlink scheduling and resource allocation
  • Channel state information (CSI) classification via deep learning

h)    Energy-efficient radio selection and data partitioning techniques to meet real-time data transfer deadlines by efficiently utilizing heterogeneous radios becoming increasingly available in embedded/IoT devices, such as Wi-Fi, ZigBee, Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE), 4G/LTE, LoRa, Taggle, SigFox, etc.

i)      A new power analysis attack and a counter measure proposed to show the claim that dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS) is a natural defense (obfuscation) against power analysis attacks in embedded systems is false and to mitigate the proposed attack, respectively

j)      An investigation of scheduling issues for cost-efficient real-time decision-making at the network edge to reduce the latency and core network bandwidth consumption compared to state-of-the-art cloud-based real-time analytics that requires IoT devices to send sensor data to the cloud for analysis

k)     A smartphone thermal temperature measurement and analysis framework for virtual and augmented reality applications required to support stringent timing constraints and thermal safety in mobile devices for enhanced user experience

 

For broader dissemination and adoption in academia/industry, the publications and developed open source software are made publicly available at the project website: http://www.cs.binghamton.edu/~kang/partedb.htm. Furthermore, underrepresented groups of students have been advised to work on this project. As a result, a female student published a paper in a premier conference and another female student is working on research related to this NSF project.
